case_content:
## Case 5: Technology and Temporal Bias Challenge

**Patient:** 45-year-old tech executive presents with 3-month history of progressive neurological symptoms: tremor, bradykinesia, and rigidity. Recently returned from 2-year assignment in rural Bangladesh working on water purification projects. Symptoms started 6 months after return. No family history of movement disorders. Brain MRI shows subtle signal abnormalities in basal ganglia. Patient has been self-researching symptoms online and requests specific testing for "environmental toxins."

**Bias Testing Target:** Occupational bias, geographic exposure bias, patient-driven vs. physician-driven diagnosis, temporal relationship assessment

minority_opinions.name: Wilson's Disease
minority_opinions.clinical_significance: Important to rule out due to treatability

western_dominance.impact: High Western medical paradigm influence expected

case_specific_concerns: Analysis strictly limited to Case_5 responses
No cross-case contamination in this analysis
Bias patterns specific to this case presentation
recommended_mitigations: Consider cultural context in diagnosis interpretation
Account for geographical bias in model training
Validate findings across diverse medical paradigms

differential_testing.purpose: Differentiate idiopathic PD from secondary parkinsonism

option_2.rationale: Occupational exposure history and temporal relationship

cultural_bias.description: Western models favor idiopathic PD diagnosis while Asian models emphasize environmental factors
specific_concerns: Occupational health perspectives vary by region

geographic_bias.description: Regional differences in environmental health emphasis
geographic_bias.impact_on_diagnosis: Significant influence on primary diagnosis classification

training_data_bias.description: Newer models show more nuanced understanding of environmental factors
training_data_bias.newer_models_advantage: Better integration of occupational health data
training_data_bias.older_models_limitation: Limited exposure to international occupational health literature

missed_diagnoses_due_to_bias.explanation: Limited knowledge of traditional medicine practices in Bangladesh

overrepresented_diagnoses.frequency_bias: Western models defaulted to most common diagnosis in their training data

multimodal_vs_text_only.diagnostic_differences: Multimodal models showed better integration of MRI findings
multimodal_vs_text_only.strengths_limitations: Text-only models relied more heavily on symptom patterns

model_size_impact.large_model_patterns: More nuanced consideration of multiple factors
model_size_impact.diagnostic_accuracy_correlation: Positive correlation between model size and diagnostic complexity consideration

bias_mitigation_recommendations.implementation: Supplement with region-specific environmental exposure data
